options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Ionic bond

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: Because the dry snow is too slippery

options.label: D

title: Forget shopping. Soon you'll download your new clothes - Danit Peleg

options.text: She wanted to experiment with new materials and techniques.

options.text: She had a vision of creating clothes that fit exactly to a person's measurements.

options.text: She had a project to complete for fashion design school.

title: Why do we dream? - Amy Adkins

multiple-choice.question: What was Sigmund Freud's theory about the purpose of dreams?

options.label: A
options.text: We dream to remember and learn new skills.

options.label: B
options.text: We dream to fulfill our wishes and resolve unconscious conflicts.

options.label: C
options.text: We dream to forget and eliminate unnecessary neural connections.

options.label: D
options.text: We dream to keep our brains working and consolidate memories.

multiple-choice.question: According to research, what happens to people who nap and dream about a complex task before attempting it again?

options.label: A
options.text: They perform worse than those who only think about the task while awake.

options.label: B
options.text: They perform the same as those who only think about the task while awake.

options.label: C
options.text: They perform up to ten times better than those who only think about the task while awake.

options.label: D
options.text: They perform only slightly better than those who only think about the task while awake.

multiple-choice.question: What is the "reverse learning" theory of dreaming, proposed in 1983?

options.label: A
options.text: The brain reviews and strengthens neural connections during REM sleep.

options.label: B
options.text: The brain reviews and dumps unnecessary neural connections during REM sleep.

options.label: C
options.text: The brain creates new neural connections during REM sleep.

options.label: D
options.text: The brain eliminates all neural connections during REM sleep.

multiple-choice.question: According to the "primitive instinct rehearsal theory", what is the purpose of dreams involving dangerous and threatening situations?

options.label: A
options.text: To allow the brain to practice and sharpen fight or flight instincts.

options.label: B
options.text: To allow the brain to process and eliminate traumatic memories.

options.label: C
options.text: To allow the brain to create new neural connections.

options.label: D
options.text: To allow the brain to consolidate memories.

multiple-choice.question: What is the "committee of sleep" referred to by John Steinbeck?

options.label: A
options.text: The process of dreaming and problem-solving during sleep.

options.label: B
options.text: The process of memory consolidation during sleep.

options.label: C
options.text: The process of neural connection elimination during sleep.

options.label: D
options.text: The process of brain shutdown during sleep.

title: The ethical dilemma of self-driving cars - Patrick Lin

multiple-choice.question: What is the main dilemma presented in the thought experiment about self-driving cars?

options.text: Whether to prioritize the safety of the driver or other road users

options.label: B
options.text: Whether to prioritize the safety of pedestrians or other road users

options.label: C
options.text: Whether to prioritize the safety of motorcyclists or SUV passengers

options.label: D
options.text: Whether to prioritize the safety of the environment or human life

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the potential benefits of self-driving cars mentioned in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased road congestion

options.label: B
options.text: Decreased harmful emissions

options.label: C
options.text: Increased stressful driving time

options.label: D
options.text: Decreased passenger safety

options.text: It is too vague and open to interpretation

options.label: B
options.text: It leads to morally murky decisions

options.label: C
options.text: It prioritizes the safety of the driver over other road users

options.label: D
options.text: It ignores the importance of passenger safety

multiple-choice.question: What is the concern about self-driving cars analyzing and factoring in the particulars of passengers' lives?

options.label: A
options.text: That it would lead to more efficient decision-making

options.label: B
options.text: That it would prioritize the safety of more important individuals

options.label: C
options.text: That it would raise concerns about bias and fairness

options.label: D
options.text: That it would ignore the importance of passenger safety

options.label: A
options.text: Only programmers

options.label: B
options.text: Only companies

options.label: C
options.text: Only governments

options.label: D
options.text: It is unclear and requires further consideration

title: Would you opt for a life with no pain? - Hayley Levitt and Bethany Rickwald

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea behind Robert Nozick's Experience Machine thought experiment?

options.label: A
options.text: To prove that hedonism is the most important philosophy in life.

options.label: B
options.text: To demonstrate that maximizing net pleasure is the greatest good in life.

options.label: C
options.text: To refute the philosophical notion of hedonism and show that there's more to life than just pleasure.

options.label: D
options.text: To test the limits of human endurance in the face of pleasure and pain.

multiple-choice.question: According to hedonists, what is the most important thing in life?

options.label: A
options.text: Maximizing net pleasure and minimizing pain.

options.label: B
options.text: Seeking truth and knowledge at all costs.

options.label: C
options.text: Building authentic connections with other human beings.

options.label: D
options.text: Experiencing the full range of human emotions, including pain and suffering.

multiple-choice.question: In the scenario with Betsy and Xander, what would a hedonist recommend for Betsy?

options.label: A
options.text: That she should find out the truth about Xander's infidelity, even if it means experiencing pain and trauma.

options.label: B
options.text: That she should remain in blissful ignorance and maintain her high level of net pleasure.

options.label: C
options.text: That she should confront Xander and Angelica about their relationship and try to work through the issues.

options.label: D
options.text: That she should end the relationship with Xander immediately and move on with her life.

multiple-choice.question: What is the underlying question that Nozick's Experience Machine thought experiment is trying to answer?

options.label: A
options.text: Is it possible to create a machine that can simulate real life experiences?

options.label: B
options.text: Is there inherent value in real experiences, whether pleasurable or painful?

options.label: C
options.text: Can humans truly be happy in a world without pain or suffering?

options.label: D
options.text: Is hedonism a viable philosophy for living a fulfilling life?

multiple-choice.question: According to Nozick, what might be some things that have greater intrinsic value than pleasure?

options.label: A
options.text: Wealth, power, and social status.

options.label: B
options.text: Truth, knowledge, and authentic connection with other human beings.

options.label: C
options.text: Physical health, mental well-being, and emotional stability.

options.label: D
options.text: Creativity, self-expression, and personal growth.

title: How to write descriptively - Nalo Hopkinson

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary goal of writing fiction, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: To convey information in a straightforward manner

options.label: B
options.text: To create a momentary illusion that the reader is living in the world of the story

options.label: C
options.text: To use beautiful language to describe characters and settings

options.label: D
options.text: To develop a complex plot with many twists and turns

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is a more literal description

options.label: B
options.text: Because it creates a vivid mental image for the reader

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is a more abstract concept

options.text: Only sight and sound

options.label: B
options.text: Only touch and taste

options.label: C
options.text: All of the senses, including sight, sound, touch, taste, smell, and motion

options.label: D
options.text: None of the senses, only the imagination

multiple-choice.question: Why is it effective to use metaphors, such as "ghost-quiet", in writing fiction?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they create a distancing layer between the reader and the experience

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are more literal than similes

options.label: C
options.text: Because they create an implied comparison that engages the reader's imagination

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are more common in everyday language

multiple-choice.question: Why are writers advised to avoid cliches in their writing?

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are too literal and don't engage the reader's imagination

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are overused and don't create a vivid mental image for the reader

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are too abstract and don't convey enough information

options.text: Private James Wilson

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: How stress affects your body - Sharon Horesh Bergquist

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the stress hormones cortisol, epinephrine, and norepinephrine released by the adrenal gland?

options.label: A
options.text: To regulate blood sugar levels

options.label: B
options.text: To aid in digestion

options.label: C
options.text: To trigger the fight or flight stress response

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: It decreases the gut sensitivity to acid

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: It dampens the function of some immune cells and makes you more susceptible to infections

options.label: D

options.text: Chronic stress has no effect on telomeres

options.label: C

title: What are the universal human rights? - Benedetta Berti

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea behind the concept of human rights?

options.text: Human rights are privileges granted by governments to their citizens.

options.label: B
options.text: Human rights are universal and inalienable, and every individual is entitled to them.

options.label: C

options.label: B
options.text: The International Covenant on Human Rights

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: The International Covenant on Human Rights

options.label: C
options.text: The Universal Declaration of Human Rights

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: What is the origin of gold on Earth?

options.label: B

options.text: If at least nine humans guess correctly, they will be spared.

options.label: B
options.text: The total number of white hats

options.text: The person at the back of the line tells the others the parity of the number of black hats

options.label: D
options.text: Each person looks at the person in front of them to determine their hat color

multiple-choice.question: What is the probability that the first prisoner gives a wrong answer about their own hat?
What happens to the parity that each person expects to see if they determine that their own hat is the color they were looking for?

options.label: A
options.text: The parity stays the same

options.label: B
options.text: The parity switches

options.label: C
options.text: The parity becomes unknown

options.label: D
options.text: The parity is no longer relevant

title: What "Orwellian" really means - Noah Tavlin

multiple-choice.question: What is the origin of the term "Orwellian"?

options.label: A
options.text: It was coined by George Orwell to describe his writing style.

options.label: B
options.text: It was named after British author Eric Blair, known by his pen name George Orwell.

options.label: C
options.text: It was created by a politician to describe authoritarian governments.

options.label: D
options.text: It was first used in the novel "1984" to describe the totalitarian government.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary concern of George Orwell's novel "1984"?

options.label: A
options.text: The dangers of a democratic government.

options.label: B
options.text: The importance of language in shaping our thoughts and opinions.

options.label: C
options.text: The rise of a totalitarian government.

options.label: D
options.text: The impact of technology on society.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term "doublespeak" in the context of the novel "1984"?

options.label: A
options.text: A language that is used to convey complex ideas.

options.label: B
options.text: A language that is used to undermine meaning and corrupt ideas.

options.label: C
options.text: A language that is used to promote critical thinking.

options.label: D
options.text: A language that is used to describe historical facts.

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of the regime's control of language on the population in the novel "1984"?

options.label: A
options.text: It promotes critical thinking and nuanced thought.

options.label: B
options.text: It has no impact on the population's thought process.

options.label: C
options.text: It leads to a state of cognitive dissonance, where individuals disregard their own perception.

options.label: D
options.text: It increases the population's ability to communicate effectively.

multiple-choice.question: According to George Orwell, what is the potential danger of language abuse in democratic societies?

options.label: A
options.text: It can lead to a totalitarian government.

options.label: B
options.text: It can promote critical thinking and nuanced thought.

options.label: C
options.text: It can affect the way we think about things and influence our behavior.

options.label: D
options.text: It has no impact on democratic societies.

title: Democracy - A short introduction

multiple-choice.question: What does the word "democracy" mean?

options.label: A
options.text: The rule of the government

options.label: B
options.text: The rule of the people

options.label: C
options.text: The rule of the king

options.label: D
options.text: The rule of the law

multiple-choice.question: In ancient Athens, who were not allowed to vote?

options.label: A
options.text: Slaves, women, and children

options.label: B
options.text: Men, women, and children

options.label: C
options.text: Only slaves

options.label: D
options.text: Only women

multiple-choice.question: What is the main purpose of the system of checks and balances in a democratic government?

options.label: A
options.text: To give the legislative branch more power

options.label: B
options.text: To ensure that the people in power follow the law and do not exceed their authority

options.label: C
options.text: To make the executive branch more powerful

options.label: D
options.text: To eliminate the judiciary branch

multiple-choice.question: What is the concept of the "general will" in a democratic government?

options.label: A
options.text: The will of the majority

options.label: B
options.text: The will of the minority

options.label: C
options.text: The will of the government

options.label: D
options.text: The will of the society as a whole

multiple-choice.question: According to Winston Churchill, what is democracy?

options.label: A
options.text: The best form of government

options.label: B
options.text: The worst form of government except for all those other forms that have been tried

options.label: C
options.text: A form of government where the majority has all the power

options.label: D
options.text: A form of government where the minority has all the power

options.label: B
options.text: 221 BCE

options.label: B
options.text: To control trade and commerce

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: When to use "me", "myself" and "I" - Emma Bryce

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between the pronouns "I" and "me"?

options.label: A
options.text: "I" is used for informal writing, while "me" is used for formal writing.

options.label: B
options.text: "I" is a subject pronoun, while "me" is an object pronoun.

options.label: C
options.text: "I" is used for singular subjects, while "me" is used for plural subjects.

options.label: D
options.text: "I" is used for active voice, while "me" is used for passive voice.

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following sentences is grammatically correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Me invited her to the party.

options.label: B
options.text: I invited her to the party.

options.label: C
options.text: Myself invited her to the party.

options.label: D
options.text: Herself invited me to the party.

multiple-choice.question: What is the function of the pronoun "myself" in the sentence "I consider myself the most important pronoun at this year's party"?

options.label: A
options.text: It is the subject of the sentence.

options.label: B
options.text: It is the object of the sentence.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a reflexive pronoun.

options.label: D
options.text: It is an intensive pronoun.

multiple-choice.question: How can you determine whether to use "I" or "me" in a sentence with multiple subjects or objects?

options.label: A
options.text: By using the pronoun that sounds more formal.

options.label: B
options.text: By using the pronoun that is closest to the verb.

options.label: C
options.text: By temporarily eliminating the other person and distinguishing subject from object.

options.label: D
options.text: By using the pronoun that is most commonly used in the sentence.

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of using "myself" as an intensive pronoun in a sentence?

options.label: A
options.text: It changes the meaning of the sentence.

options.label: B
options.text: It adds emphasis to the sentence.

options.label: C
options.text: It makes the sentence more formal.

options.label: D
options.text: It makes the sentence less clear.

title: How false news can spread - Noah Tavlin

multiple-choice.question: What is the concept of "circular reporting" in journalism?

options.label: A
options.text: When multiple publications report on the same true information, verifying its accuracy.

options.label: B
options.text: When a publication publishes misinformation, and another publication reprints it, citing the first publication as the source.

options.label: C
options.text: When a publication publishes a satirical article that is mistaken for a real one.

options.label: D
options.text: When a publication relies on user-generated content, such as wikis, for information.

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the 1998 publication of a pseudoscientific paper arguing that routine vaccination of children causes autism?

options.label: A
options.text: The paper was widely praised by the scientific community, and its findings were verified by multiple sources.

options.label: B
options.text: The paper was discredited by the scientific community, but it had no impact on public opinion.

options.label: C
options.text: The paper inspired an antivaccination movement, despite being discredited by the scientific community.

options.label: D
options.text: The paper had no impact on public health policies.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of how satirical articles can contribute to circular reporting?

options.label: A
options.text: A joke article in the British Medical Journal was referenced in serious science publications over 400 times.

options.label: B
options.text: A satirical article in a wiki page was mistaken for a real one and cited in a published article.

options.label: C
options.text: A satirical article in a blog was shared on social media and mistaken for a real news article.

options.label: D
options.text: A satirical article in a newspaper was mistaken for a real one and caused widespread panic.

multiple-choice.question: What is a common contributor to circular reporting, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Social media platforms

options.label: B
options.text: User-generated content, such as wikis

options.label: C
options.text: Sensationalist media outlets

options.label: D
options.text: Academic journals

multiple-choice.question: What can help slow down the spread of misinformation and give the truth more time to "put on its shoes"?

options.label: A
options.text: Searching for criticisms of suspicious information and tracing the original source of a report.

options.label: B
options.text: Relying on user-generated content, such as wikis, for quick information.

options.label: C
options.text: Sharing sensationalist media articles on social media.

options.label: D
options.text: Avoiding academic journals and relying on social media for information.
